intro: Digitalis ferruginea subsp. schischkinii, commonly known as the Schischkin's foxglove, is a perennial herb native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It belongs to the Plantaginaceae family and is characterized by its striking, tubular flowers that range in color from pink to purple. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with lance-shaped leaves that are covered in fine hairs. It prefers well-drained, alkaline soils and is often found in rocky or limestone-rich habitats. Due to its ornamental value and medicinal properties, it is occasionally cultivated in gardens and botanical collections.
